trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory Identity Protection flows| Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory Identity Protection flows| Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Provides an overview of the user experience when Identity Protection has mitigated or remediated a user or when multi-factor authentication is required by a policy.
trans-unit.target: Provides an overview of the user experience when Identity Protection has mitigated or remediated a user or when multi-factor authentication is required by a policy.

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory Identity Protection flows
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory Identity Protection flows

trans-unit.source: With Azure Active Directory Identity Protection, you can:
trans-unit.target: With Azure Active Directory Identity Protection, you can:

trans-unit.source: require users to register for multi-factor authentication
trans-unit.target: require users to register for multi-factor authentication

trans-unit.source: handle risky sign-ins and compromised users
trans-unit.target: handle risky sign-ins and compromised users

trans-unit.source: The response of the system to these issues has an impact on a user's sign-in experience because just directly signing-in by providing a user name and a password won't be possible anymore.
trans-unit.target: The response of the system to these issues has an impact on a user's sign-in experience because just directly signing-in by providing a user name and a password won't be possible anymore.

trans-unit.source: Additional steps are required to get a user safely back into business.
trans-unit.target: Additional steps are required to get a user safely back into business.

trans-unit.source: This topic gives you an overview of a user's sign-in experience for all cases that can occur.
trans-unit.target: This topic gives you an overview of a user's sign-in experience for all cases that can occur.

trans-unit.source: Multi-factor authentication
trans-unit.target: Multi-factor authentication

trans-unit.source: Multi-factor authentication registration
trans-unit.target: Multi-factor authentication registration

trans-unit.source: Sign-in at risk
trans-unit.target: Sign-in at risk

trans-unit.source: Risky sign-in recovery
trans-unit.target: Risky sign-in recovery

trans-unit.source: Risky sign-in blocked
trans-unit.target: Risky sign-in blocked

trans-unit.source: Multi-factor authentication registration during a risky sign-in
trans-unit.target: Multi-factor authentication registration during a risky sign-in

trans-unit.source: User at risk
trans-unit.target: User at risk

trans-unit.source: Compromised account recovery
trans-unit.target: Compromised account recovery

trans-unit.source: Compromised account blocked
trans-unit.target: Compromised account blocked

trans-unit.source: Multi-factor authentication registration
trans-unit.target: Multi-factor authentication registration

trans-unit.source: The best user experience for both, the compromised account recovery flow and the risky sign-in flow, is when the user can self-recover.
trans-unit.target: The best user experience for both, the compromised account recovery flow and the risky sign-in flow, is when the user can self-recover.

trans-unit.source: If users are registered for multi-factor authentication, they already have a phone number associated with their account that can be used to pass security challenges.
trans-unit.target: If users are registered for multi-factor authentication, they already have a phone number associated with their account that can be used to pass security challenges.

trans-unit.source: No help desk or administrator involvement is needed to recover from account compromise.
trans-unit.target: No help desk or administrator involvement is needed to recover from account compromise.

trans-unit.source: Thus, it’s highly recommended to get your users registered for multi-factor authentication.
trans-unit.target: Thus, it’s highly recommended to get your users registered for multi-factor authentication.

trans-unit.source: Administrators can:
trans-unit.target: Administrators can:

trans-unit.source: set a policy that requires users to set up their accounts for additional security verification.
trans-unit.target: set a policy that requires users to set up their accounts for additional security verification.

trans-unit.source: allow skipping multi-factor authentication registration for up to 30 days, in case they want to give users a grace period before registering.
trans-unit.target: allow skipping multi-factor authentication registration for up to 30 days, in case they want to give users a grace period before registering.

trans-unit.source: The multi-factor authentication registration has three steps:
trans-unit.target: The multi-factor authentication registration has three steps:

trans-unit.source: In the first step, the user gets a notification about the requirement to set the account up for multi-factor authentication.
trans-unit.target: In the first step, the user gets a notification about the requirement to set the account up for multi-factor authentication.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: To set multi-factor authentication up, you need to let the system know how you want to be contacted.
trans-unit.target: To set multi-factor authentication up, you need to let the system know how you want to be contacted.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: The system submits a challenge to you and you need to respond.
trans-unit.target: The system submits a challenge to you and you need to respond.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: Risky sign-in recovery
trans-unit.target: Risky sign-in recovery

trans-unit.source: When an administrator has configured a policy for sign-in risks, the affected users are notified when they try to sign-in.
trans-unit.target: When an administrator has configured a policy for sign-in risks, the affected users are notified when they try to sign-in.

trans-unit.source: The risky sign-in flow has two steps:
trans-unit.target: The risky sign-in flow has two steps:

trans-unit.source: The user is informed that something unusual was detected about their sign-in, such as signing in from a new location, device, or app.
trans-unit.target: The user is informed that something unusual was detected about their sign-in, such as signing in from a new location, device, or app.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: The user is required to prove their identity by solving a security challenge.
trans-unit.target: The user is required to prove their identity by solving a security challenge.

trans-unit.source: If the user is registered for multi-factor authentication they need to round-trip a security code to their phone number.
trans-unit.target: If the user is registered for multi-factor authentication they need to round-trip a security code to their phone number.

trans-unit.source: Since this is a just a risky sign in and not a compromised account, the user won’t have to change the password in this flow.
trans-unit.target: Since this is a just a risky sign in and not a compromised account, the user won’t have to change the password in this flow.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: Risky sign-in blocked
trans-unit.target: Risky sign-in blocked

trans-unit.source: Administrators can also choose to set a Sign-In Risk policy to block users upon sign-in depending on the risk level.
trans-unit.target: Administrators can also choose to set a Sign-In Risk policy to block users upon sign-in depending on the risk level.

trans-unit.source: To get unblocked, end users must contact an administrator or help desk, or they can try signing in from a familiar location or device.
trans-unit.target: To get unblocked, end users must contact an administrator or help desk, or they can try signing in from a familiar location or device.

trans-unit.source: Self-recovering by solving multi-factor authentication is not an option in this case.
trans-unit.target: Self-recovering by solving multi-factor authentication is not an option in this case.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: Multi-factor authentication registration during a risky sign-in
trans-unit.target: Multi-factor authentication registration during a risky sign-in

trans-unit.source: It is important that users register for multi-factor authentication so that they are prepared and able to pass security challenges.
trans-unit.target: It is important that users register for multi-factor authentication so that they are prepared and able to pass security challenges.

trans-unit.source: If a user isn’t registered for multi-factor authentication but the policy requires them to be, they could be asked to register during a risky sign-in.
trans-unit.target: If a user isn’t registered for multi-factor authentication but the policy requires them to be, they could be asked to register during a risky sign-in.

trans-unit.source: This means, an attacker could end up being asked to add a phone number instead of the good user.
trans-unit.target: This means, an attacker could end up being asked to add a phone number instead of the good user.

trans-unit.source: To avoid this situation, require users to register for multi-factor authentication as soon as possible, so that a phone number is already associated with their account in case they ever get compromised.
trans-unit.target: To avoid this situation, require users to register for multi-factor authentication as soon as possible, so that a phone number is already associated with their account in case they ever get compromised.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, administrators can completely block compromised users who aren’t registered for multi-factor authentication.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, administrators can completely block compromised users who aren’t registered for multi-factor authentication.

trans-unit.source: The multi-factor authentication registration during a risky sign-in has two steps:
trans-unit.target: The multi-factor authentication registration during a risky sign-in has two steps:

trans-unit.source: The user is notified that the account is at risk.
trans-unit.target: The user is notified that the account is at risk.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: The multi-factor authentication registration process is initiated.
trans-unit.target: The multi-factor authentication registration process is initiated.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: For the next steps, see [Multi-factor authentication registration](#multi-factor-authentication-registration)
trans-unit.target: For the next steps, see [Multi-factor authentication registration](#multi-factor-authentication-registration)

trans-unit.source: Compromised account recovery
trans-unit.target: Compromised account recovery

trans-unit.source: When a user risk security policy has been configured, users who meet the user risk level specified in the policy (and are therefore assumed compromised) must go through the user compromise recovery flow before they can sign-in.
trans-unit.target: When a user risk security policy has been configured, users who meet the user risk level specified in the policy (and are therefore assumed compromised) must go through the user compromise recovery flow before they can sign-in.

trans-unit.source: The user compromise recovery flow has three steps:
trans-unit.target: The user compromise recovery flow has three steps:

trans-unit.source: The user is informed that their account security is at risk because of suspicious activity or leaked credentials.
trans-unit.target: The user is informed that their account security is at risk because of suspicious activity or leaked credentials.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: The user is required to prove their identity by solving a security challenge.
trans-unit.target: The user is required to prove their identity by solving a security challenge.

trans-unit.source: If the user is registered for multi-factor authentication they can self-recover from being compromised.
trans-unit.target: If the user is registered for multi-factor authentication they can self-recover from being compromised.

trans-unit.source: They will need to round-trip a security code to their phone number.
trans-unit.target: They will need to round-trip a security code to their phone number.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: Finally, the user is forced to change their password since someone else may have had access to their account.
trans-unit.target: Finally, the user is forced to change their password since someone else may have had access to their account.

trans-unit.source: Screenshots of this experience are below.
trans-unit.target: Screenshots of this experience are below.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: Compromised account blocked
trans-unit.target: Compromised account blocked

trans-unit.source: To get a user that was blocked by a user risk security policy unblocked, the user must contact an administrator or help desk.
trans-unit.target: To get a user that was blocked by a user risk security policy unblocked, the user must contact an administrator or help desk.

trans-unit.source: Self-recovering by solving multi-factor authentication is not an option in this case.
trans-unit.target: Self-recovering by solving multi-factor authentication is not an option in this case.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: Reset password
trans-unit.target: Reset password

trans-unit.source: If compromised users are blocked from signing in, an administrator can generate a temporary password for them.
trans-unit.target: If compromised users are blocked from signing in, an administrator can generate a temporary password for them.

trans-unit.source: The users will have to change their password during a next sign-in.
trans-unit.target: The users will have to change their password during a next sign-in.

trans-unit.source: Remediation
trans-unit.target: Remediation

trans-unit.source: See also
trans-unit.target: See also

trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory Identity Protection
